Russell, Malgorzata, Jamie, Chris, Joshua, thank you for your time, it 
was great to meet you all today.


Thank you for this fun initiative.


Here is Nodera's feed for today.


Guillaume Fauconnier & Carla Martin


  Today's Questions

*1: When you think about the environmental impact of software, who comes 
to mind as responsible for it? And why did that person or group come to 
mind?*

*
*

*It is the user who is the ultimate decider. Without users there is no 
need, no electriciy to feed the computers and thus no impact. But the to 
its defense, the user cuurently has limited and/or incorrect information 
about the environmental impact of the software it relies on.*


*2: In your experience, who is currently making decisions about the 
environmental impact of software? Is it the right set of people? 
Building on the answer from question 1, people feeding the information 
relied on by the users to assess the environmental of software are 
indirectly making decisions. Depending on the motivation/objectives of 
the people providing the information, they might willingly or 
unwillingly lead the users to take actions that will adversly affect the 
environmental impact of the software. Case in point are the SLA's from 
cloud providers that rarely provide the user with the necessary 
information relating to the electricity used (local carbon intensity, 
price) to behave in a manner that would reduce the environmental impact. 
Most of the the time, the environmental impact is reported ex-post 
without incentive or adverse consequences. "Last month you have run 30 
red lights", but no incentive to drive in a more responsible manner.*


*3: What barriers have you or your organization encountered when trying 
to address software's environmental impact? The quality of the 
information provided regarding the electricity used is generally of very 
aggregated level like national averages whereas what is required is 
local forecast with the right financial and/or social incentives for the 
user to behave in a manner that will minimize its environmental impact 
of software usage. This very local information would also impact 
hardware decisions: building locations, cooling inertia management.
